channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Philadelphia DA sues Elon Musk over $1 million giveaway to registered voters
item.description: The suit alleges that Musk and his super PAC are luring voters to give up identifying information in pursuit of a cash prize. DA Larry Krasner called the scheme “indisputably an unlawful lottery.”
item.content:encoded:
The suit alleges that Musk and his super PAC are luring voters to give up identifying information in pursuit of a cash prize. DA Larry Krasner called the scheme “indisputably an unlawful lottery.”

(Image credit: Michael Swensen)
item.dc:creator: Alana Wise

item.title: A Fight Over Identity in Japan
item.description: Japan is the only country where married couples are required to use one surname or family name. Most often it's women who give up their surname and women's rights advocates have fought for decades for the right to use different surnames in marriage. And now proponents are using a new argument to make their point.
item.content:encoded: Japan is the only country where married couples are required to use one surname or family name. Most often it's women who give up their surname and women's rights advocates have fought for decades for the right to use different surnames in marriage. And now proponents are using a new argument to make their point.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Kuhn

item.title: Ballots set on fire in three states as Election Day approaches
item.description: Federal officials have been warning that in recent months, some social media users have been encouraging sabotage of ballot drop boxes. "It's a direct attack on democracy," said one local official.
item.content:encoded:
Federal officials have been warning that in recent months, some social media users have been encouraging sabotage of ballot drop boxes. "It's a direct attack on democracy," said one local official.

(Image credit: Erik Neumann)
item.dc:creator: Lisa Hagen

item.title: Over 200,000 subscribers flee 'Washington Post' after Bezos blocks Harris endorsement
item.description: Over 200,000 people canceled their subscriptions in the first few days following news that The Washington Post would not endorse any presidential candidate.
item.content:encoded:
Over 200,000 people canceled their subscriptions in the first few days following news that The Washington Post would not endorse any presidential candidate.

(Image credit: Evan Agostini)
item.dc:creator: David Folkenflik

item.title: Imposters stole thousands of pounds of posh cheddar, rattling the U.K. cheese world
item.description: A London distributor says thieves posing as a French client stole some $389,000 worth of cheddar. The tight-knit U.K. cheese community is on high alert — and asking people to help sniff out the goods.
item.content:encoded: A London distributor says thieves posing as a French client stole some $389,000 worth of cheddar. The tight-knit U.K. cheese community is on high alert — and asking people to help sniff out the goods.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Treisman

item.title: Israel awaits the U.S. election before a Gaza cease-fire, an official says
item.description: Egypt has a new cease-fire proposal amid Israel’s bombardment and siege of northern Gaza. Israel is discussing the proposal but waiting to see who is elected U.S. president, an official told NPR.
item.content:encoded:
Egypt has a new cease-fire proposal amid Israel’s bombardment and siege of northern Gaza. Israel is discussing the proposal but waiting to see who is elected U.S. president, an official told NPR.

(Image credit: Omar El Qattaa)
item.dc:creator: Daniel Estrin

item.title: New Dwyane Wade statue honors the NBA star. But some fans say it misses the mark
item.description: The statue was months in the making. Upon its unveiling Sunday, fans suggested it looks more like former professional boxer George Foreman and Matrix actor Laurence Fishburne.
item.content:encoded:
The statue was months in the making. Upon its unveiling Sunday, fans suggested it looks more like former professional boxer George Foreman and Matrix actor Laurence Fishburne.

(Image credit: Michael Laughlin)
item.dc:creator: Juliana Kim

item.title: How culture wars divided one small progressive church in Philadelphia
item.description: Journalist Eliza Griswold says complaints about homophobia, white privilege and diversity are splintering progressive organizations — including one particular church. Her book is Circle of Hope.
item.content:encoded:
Journalist Eliza Griswold says complaints about homophobia, white privilege and diversity are splintering progressive organizations — including one particular church. Her book is Circle of Hope.

(Image credit: Seamus Murphy)
item.dc:creator: Terry Gross

item.title: Many Palestinian citizens of Israel live in fear amid a backlash after Hamas' attack
item.description: Palestinian citizens of Israel say they live in an atmosphere of fear, facing a backlash from Israeli society and arrests by authorities since the Hamas-led attack in southern Israel last year.
item.content:encoded:
Palestinian citizens of Israel say they live in an atmosphere of fear, facing a backlash from Israeli society and arrests by authorities since the Hamas-led attack in southern Israel last year.

(Image credit: Ayman Oghanna for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Hadeel Al-Shalchi

item.title: Tonally inconsistent ‘Dragon Age: The Veilguard’ is still BioWare’s best action game
item.description: Dragon Age: The Veilguard has superb combat and charismatic companions but if you're hoping for a return to the series' origins, you'll be disappointed.
item.content:encoded:
Dragon Age: The Veilguard has superb combat and charismatic companions but if you're hoping for a return to the series' origins, you'll be disappointed.

(Image credit: Andy Bickerton/BioWare)
item.dc:creator: Andy Bickerton
